title: Japan bans baby names like Pikachu and Kitty
description: Japan changes the law to stop parents giving their children names considered strange.
story:
Japan has changed the law to stop people naming their babies things like Pikachu and Kitty.

New rules have come in on the pronunciation of ‘kanji’, the Chinese characters used as one of the three forms of Japanese writing.

The change is designed to prevent unofficial pronunciations of the kanji characters. In recent times, these unusual interpretations of the characters have allowed people to call their children names which are seen as strange or silly by the authorities.

    • take aim at something try to deal with an issue; criticise something.
  • She took aim at her rival for the job promotion by pointing out all his weaknesses.

title: Australia teen social media ban
description: Australia's social media ban for under-16s has started.
story:
Children under the age of 16 in Australia are no longer allowed to have social media accounts – by law.

The ban includes TikTok, X, Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, Snapchat and Threads.

The Australian government says the ban will reduce the negative impact of features that encourage children to spend time on screens, potentially being exposed to harmful content.

Critics of the ban say that children will not get the social contact they need and might be tempted to search in darker parts of the internet.
headlines: Australia’s social media ban comes into force The Observer Here are the platforms that will be included in the under-16s social media ban. But there's a caveat 9News Australia leader defends social media ban as teens brag about staying online BusinessWorld

     speak with too much pride about something you have or have achieved

title: Our world in English: Love in a warzone
description: Adela falls in love and moves to Kharkiv in Ukraine. Adapted from a BBC Eye documentary.

title: Syria: One year since Assad's fall
description: It's one year since Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad was forced to leave the capital.
story:
The 8th of December marked a year since Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad was forced to leave the capital, Damascus. Assad’s regime, or way of governing, was marked by civil war and brutal attacks on pro-democracy protesters.

Ahmed al-Sharaa became the country’s president. Al-Sharaa is a former al-Qaeda fighter who led the rebel group which removed Assad from power.

In a speech to the nation on Monday, he promised to build a Syria for all Syrians, saying the country had broken away from its past of repression and violence.

Syrians gathered at home and abroad to celebrate the year anniversary of the fall of the Assad regime, whether they agree with President al-Sharaa or oppose him.
headlines: Taking stock of Sharaa’s rule in Syria, one year after the fall of Assad France 24 Can Syria’s president turn wave of global goodwill into tangible results at home? The Guardian Jeremy Bowen: Syria feels lighter without the Assads' crushing weight - but now there are new problems BBC News

taking stock carefully evaluate or review a situation

    • tangible real and noticeable
  • The training programme showed tangible results in test scores.
    • crushing weight a heavy feeling of pressure which makes life difficult
  • My manager gave me the project and now I’m feeling the crushing weight of responsibility to get this right.

title: Deadly fires in Hong Kong investigated
description: Hong Kong leader orders investigation into deadly fires which killed at least 151 people
story:
Hong Kong leader John Lee has ordered the creation of an independent committee to investigate the cause of a fire which killed at least 151 people.

The fire spread quickly across seven residential high-rise tower blocks in Tai Po on Wednesday last week.

Building work was happening on the tower blocks, and authorities have since said that the materials being used, such as netting on the outside of the towers, caused the fire to spread more quickly.

At least 13 people have been arrested on suspicion of manslaughter, including the directors of a construction company.
headlines: Authorities probe corruption and negligence in Hong Kong’s deadliest fire in decades AP News Hong Kong mourners queue to pay respects after deadly Tai Po fire Euronews China cracks down on calls for accountability over deadly Hong Kong blaze Al Jazeera

    • crack down on (something) start dealing with something more harshly or seriously
  • In her election campaign, the politician promised to crack down on unemployment.

title: First treasure recovered from $20bn sunken ship
description: A ship that sunk in 1708 is thought to have $20bn worth of treasure on it
story:
A cannon, three coins and a porcelain cup have been recovered from a ship that sank over 300 years ago.

The ship, called the San Jose, was sunk by British ships in 1708, near Cartagena in Colombia.

San Jose is thought to have $20bn worth of gold and silver coins on board, according to some estimates.

Colombia, Spain, an American company and indigenous groups in Bolivia have all claimed that this treasure belongs to them.
headlines: Archeologists recover treasures from the legendary 1708 San Jose, wrecked in war Fox Weather First treasures from ' holy grail of shipwrecks' recovered Sky News Coins, cannon recovered from legendary ship that sunk 3 centuries ago with billions of dollars in treasure CBS News

title: Death penalty for former Bangladesh prime minister Sheikh Hasina
description: The former prime minister of Bangladesh has been sentenced to death
story:
Former Prime Minister of Bangladesh, Sheikh Hasina, has been sentenced to death by a court in Dhaka for crimes against humanity.

Last July she ordered a crackdown on student protests which resulted in the deaths of up to 1,400 people, according to the UN.

As a result of the protests, Hasina escaped to India, where she still is. An interim government took power in Bangladesh.

Hasina had also been accused of a number of human rights violations while she was in power.
headlines: Ousted Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for crimes against humanity The Guardian 'Unelected, Illegal Regime's Sham Of A Verdict': Sheikh Hasina's Son To NDTV NDTV Bangladesh signals that no leader is above the law by sentencing Sheikh Hasina to death The Conversation

title: COP30: Are climate talks effective at fighting climate change?
description: International leaders gather for COP30 climate talks.
story:
Two weeks of international climate talks began this week in Belém in Brazil. COP is an annual gathering of politicians and negotiators from around the world to discuss climate change and make agreements to help deal with the problem. 

Some important people have decided not to attend, such as US President Donald Trump. Some experts think that because some powerful leaders aren’t attending the talks, they won’t make any progress, although others believe the negotiations are still very important for fighting climate change.

In a speech on the first day of the talks, Brazilian president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva warned about the dangers of fake news and climate deniers, people who incorrectly argue that human-caused climate change is not real.
headlines: Who are the major players at Cop30 and what do they want? The Guardian COP30: Trump and many leaders are skipping it, so does the summit still have a point ? BBC News Muted global business turnout at COP30 reflects subdued mood The Financial Times

  • The CEO’s new ideas received a muted response from staff at the company meeting.

title: Fastest glacier melt in modern history
description: An Antarctic glacier shrunk by 50% in just two months.
story:
In late 2022, an Antarctic glacier, named Hektoria, shrunk by nearly 50% in just two months.

According to a new study, this was the fastest a glacier has retreated that scientists have recorded in modern history. Retreated means it melted and got smaller. 

Hektoria is a type of glacier which rests on the seabed and doesn’t float. Glaciers like this generally retreat only a few hundred metres a year. But between November and December 2022, Hektoria retreated by 8 km, according to the study.

Scientists are concerned because if more glaciers like this shrink as quickly, there could be a much faster rise in sea-level.
headlines: Antarctic glacier's alarming retreat is the fastest ever seen New Scientist  Antarctic glacier saw the fastest retreat in modern history; it could spell trouble for sea levels, report finds CNN Antarctic glacier's rapid retreat sparks scientific ' whodunnit ' BBC News

title: 'Storm of the century' hits Caribbean
description: Hurricane Melissa is the strongest hurricane in modern history to hit Jamaica
story:
Category five hurricane Melissa hit Jamaica on Tuesday with violent winds reaching a high of 295 km/h. The storm them hit Cuba on Wednesday morning.

The Jamaican Prime Minister has declared the country a "disaster area" and warns of "devastating impacts".

It will take time to know exactly how bad the damage is, but we know homes and hospitals have been badly affected and there is severe flooding across Jamaica.

It is the strongest storm on Earth so far this year and is one of the strongest storms in the Atlantic Ocean this century.
headlines: Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in Jamaica The Guardian As the Atlantic Ocean warms, climate change is fueling Hurricane Melissa’s ferocity AP News Storm chasers fly inside the eye of Hurricane Melissa BBC News

title: Historic jewels stolen from Louvre
description: Historic jewels, worth millions of euros have been stolen from the Louvre museum in Paris
story:
Thieves broke into the Louvre museum in Paris on Sunday morning and stole eight extremely valuable items of jewellery.

The robbers used power tools to break into the museum, which is the famous home of the Mona Lisa painting.

The thieves escaped on scooters, and took items including tiaras and necklaces, that belonged to French royalty or imperial rulers. The entire break in took about seven minutes.
headlines: In Just 7 Brazen Minutes, Thieves Grab ‘ Priceless ’ Jewels From Louvre New York Times Louvre heist: thieves steal crown jewels in daylight burglary The Times ' Race against time ' as police try to recover 'priceless' jewels from Louvre - as authorities reveal details of daring raid Sky News

title: Hostages released in Gaza ceasefire agreement
description: Israeli hostages and Palestinian detainees were exchanged on Monday
story:
Israelis and Palestinians have celebrated after hostages and prisoners were exchanged on Monday.

Hamas returned all living Israeli hostages, while Israel freed almost 2,000 Palestinian prisoners and detainees.

This exchange is a big step towards ending the war in Gaza and is the first phase of a plan to end the war, arranged and negotiated by US President Donald Trump.

At a summit in Sharm el-Sheikh later on Monday, Egypt, Qatar, Turkey and the US signed a declaration backing a ceasefire deal.
headlines: Israeli hostages and Palestinian detainees freed as Trump hails ' historic dawn ' in Middle East BBC News One Era Ends in Gaza, and Another Begins The Atlantic Trump’s hostage deal was the easy part The New Statesman

title: Solar and wind beat coal for first time
description: More electricity has been generated through wind and solar power than coal for 1st time
story:
For the first time ever, more electricity has been generated through wind and solar power than from coal power plants. That's according to a new report.

The amount of electricity used globally has increased since last year, but 100% of that increase has been met by renewable energy sources.

China and India are responsible for a large part of this growth of renewable energy. Europe and the US actually increased their coal and gas power generation. 

It has been predicted that renewable energy generation could double by the end of the decade.
headlines: Global renewable energy generation surpasses coal for first time The Guardian Renewables overtake coal as world’s primary source of electricity Semafor Solar and wind power has grown faster than electricity demand this year, report says AP News

title: Taliban cut off internet
description: Afghanistan's Taliban Government has cut internet services in the country
story:
Internet and many telephones services have been cut in Afghanistan, on the orders of the country's Taliban government.

After women and girls over 12 were barred from schools, universities and many types of jobs, many of them used the internet to study online, or to sell products abroad. This shutdown has stopped from being able to do this.

Human rights organisations are concerned about the impact that this could have on girls' education in the country.
headlines: ‘Total internet blackout’ in Afghanistan sparks panic after Taliban vowed to stamp out immoral activities CNN Taliban cut internet for whole country as Afghanistan ‘dragged into abyss ’ The Independent Afghan women lose their ' last hope ' as Taliban shuts down internet BBC News

title: Trump's unproven autism claim
description: Donald Trump has made the unproven claim there's a link between autism and Tylenol.
story:
US President Donald Trump has said that there is a link between autism and the pain-relieving drug Tylenol, also known as paracetamol.

Medical experts disagree with these claims, with some calling the president's comments dangerous.

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, who are experts in women’s health, said the announcement was "unsettling" and not based on "reliable data".

Trump and RFK Jr. make autism announcement as Tylenol maker and medical experts push back

title: Israel committing genocide in Gaza: UN commission
description: A UN commission of inquiry says that Israel has committed genocide in Gaza.
story:
An investigation by the United Nations, called a 'commission of inquiry', has found that Israel has committed genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.

There are five acts of genocide defined under international law, and this report says that four out of the five acts have been carried out by Israel since the start of the war with Hamas in 2023.

The report also says there is evidence of genocidal intent in statements by Israeli leaders, and the actions of Israeli forces.

Israel's foreign ministry has rejected the report, saying that it is "distorted and false".

Human rights experts join rising chorus that accuses Israel of genocide in Gaza The Independent
 UN inquiry says Israel’s war on Gaza is genocide, holds gov’t responsible Al Jazeera

title: 'God's influencer': First millennial saint named
description: Catholic church names 15-year-old boy the first millennial saint.
story:
A boy who died at the age of 15 has been made a saint by the Catholic Church.

Carlo Acutis died in 2006 from leukaemia. He became interested in Catholicism as a child and showed an interest in helping others.

He was a keen gamer who was interested in computers, and had created websites to document religious miracles and helped run pages for Catholic organisations.
headlines:
Carlo Acutis, nicknamed 'God's influencer', becomes the first 'millennial' saint CNN Pope Leo XIV declares teen computer whiz Carlo Acutis the first millennial saint ABC News, USA Carlo and the call to evangelise in the digital age
OSV News

title: Earthquakes hit Afghanistan
description: Earthquakes in Afghanistan kill over 1,400 people
story:
A major aftershock has hit eastern Afghanistan, just days after an earthquake measuring 6.0 on the Richter scale hit the region.

More than 1,400 people have been killed and 3,000 more injured, according to the Taliban government.

The region is difficult to access because it is mountainous, and rescuers have been searching for people trapped under mud and stone homes in the area. Entire villages have been destroyed.
headlines:
Second Afghan quake brings more trauma to the shattered region SBS Australia Aid effort underway after Afghanistan quake ‘wipes out’ villages
UN News Earthquake adds to 'perfect storm' of problems hitting Afghanistan, says UN Sky News

title: Heatwaves speed up ageing process, study says
description: A study in Taiwan has found that peoples' biological age increases during heatwaves.
story:
A study in Taiwan has found that peoples' biological age increases when they experience heatwaves. Researchers measured participants' organ function in order to determine their biological age.

Experiencing four heatwave days over a two-year period led people's biological age to increase by about nine days.

Manual workers, those living in rural areas or those who do not have access to air conditioning are worse affected by heatwaves.
headlines: Heatwaves are making people age faster, study suggests The Guardian Repeated heatwaves may accelerate ageing Scimex The demographics at risk of ageing due to heatwaves The Independent

    • accelerate get faster or more intense
  • As time went on, his illness accelerated.
    • demographic a group of people who share a characteristic
  • We hope our new product will allow us to appeal a new demographic.

title: Ukraine: Presidents discuss end to war
description: President Zelensky met President Trump days after Trump met President Putin in Alaska
story:
Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky returned to the White House on Monday to meet US President Donald Trump for new talks aimed at ending the war in Ukraine.

Several European leaders also flew to Washington to attend the meeting, days after Trump met Russia's President Vladimir Putin in Alaska.

The leaders discussed a possible ‘security guarantee’ which would involve European countries and the US helping protect Ukraine if a peace deal was reached with Russia. 

Donald Trump says he doesn’t believe a ceasefire between Ukraine and Russia is necessary to end the war and that an agreement can be reached between the countries.

But other leaders are concerned about negotiations, and don’t want to accept Putin’s demands – for example, to keep land captured by Russian forces in Ukraine.
headlines: What both sides want from crunch talks at the White House BBC News Europe’s Leaders Headed Off Giveaway to Putin, but Emerged Without a Clear Path New York Times Four key takeaways from Trump’s White House summit on Ukraine The Guardian

title: Is prostate cancer over-treated?
description: Charity Prostate Cancer UK says some people are being treated when they don't need to be.
story:
The charity Prostate Cancer UK, says that the UK is treating too many patients for prostate cancer where the cancer is unlikely to cause harm. This is because sometimes the cancer grows very slowly.

According to the charity, around one in four cases could be monitored instead of treated, allowing patients to avoid harmful side effects of treatment.

The charity has criticised current guidance from the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, known as NICE. NICE says it’s reviewing this guidance.

Prostate Cancer UK says that there should be a greater focus on screening, which is widespread testing, so that the illness can be spotted at an earlier stage.

‘ Outdated guidance’ sees thousands at risk of prostate cancer ‘overtreatment’ LBC
Swindon research raises concerns over prostate cancer treatment contradictions Greatest Hits Radio
Harmful: Thousands of men given ‘unneccesary’ prostate cancer treatment every year due to ‘ wild west ’ guidelines The Sun

title: Hiroshima: 80 years since atomic bomb
description: 80 years ago the United States dropped an atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Hiroshima.
story:
80 years ago, on 6th August 1945, the United States dropped an atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Hiroshima. The aim was to force a quick end to World War Two. The bomb destroyed the city of Hiroshima and about 140,000 people were killed. 

Hiroshima was the world's first nuclear attack, and it's the only time in history that nuclear weapons have been used in warfare.

The threat of using nuclear weapons, and even nuclear war, is still high in the world. At the time of the Hiroshima bombings, only the USA had nuclear weapons. Now nine countries have them, including Russia, China and the UK.
headlines: Hiroshima at 80: Remembering the bomb, reimagining peace Gulf News Nuclear threat still hangs over our world, 80 years on Business Times Hiroshima’s fading legacy: the race to secure survivors’ memories amid a new era of nuclear brinkmanship The Guardian

  • The government said the teachers' threat to go on strike was brinkmanship.

title: Thailand-Cambodia conflict
description: There have been military clashes at the Thailand-Cambodia border, with civilians killed.
story:
Fighting broke out last week on the border between Thailand and Cambodia leading to the deaths of at least 33 people and causing thousands of people to leave their homes.

The exact border between the two countries has been disputed for many years – there are some areas which both countries claim to be theirs.

Disagreement over the border goes back to 1907 when Cambodia was a French colony and a treaty was signed. Recent political developments in each country have also contributed to the current crisis.

title: War in Gaza 'must end now', 28 countries say
description: 28 nations have demanded an end to the war in Gaza and the release of Israeli hostages.
story:
A joint statement from 28 nations has demanded an end to the war in Gaza and the release of Israeli hostages. The statement says the 'suffering of civilians in Gaza has reached new depths', meaning it is worse than ever.

More than 100 aid agencies say mass starvation is spreading across Gaza.

Over 59,000 have been killed since Israel launched its offensive after the Hamas-led attacks on 7 October 2023, according to Gaza's health ministry, run by Hamas.

Israel has rejected the criticism in the joint statement from the 28 countries as being 'disconnected from reality'.
headlines: Foreign ministers of 28 countries call for immediate ceasefire in Gaza Euro News UK and 27 nations accuse Israel of ' drip feeding ' aid to Gaza civilians as they condemn 'horrifying' killings BBC As over 25 countries demand end to Gaza war, Israel points fingers at Hamas ynetnews

title: India Air crash report doubts
description: What caused the Air India crash? And why is the preliminary report being criticised?
story:
On the 12 June, Air India flight 171 from Ahmedabad to London crashed less than a minute after take-off, killing 241 people on board and 19 on the ground.

The preliminary report, published by India's Air Accident Investigation Bureau, has caused controversy. It has been criticised by aviation experts and the Indian commercial pilots association. 

The investigators have been accused of not giving enough details, which may lead people to an incorrect conclusion.
headlines: As theories swirl about Air India crash, key details remain unknown BBC News Air India crash: What AAIB report confirms, what it rules out, what still remains unanswered Times of India Was the Air India crash caused by pilot error or technical fault? None of the theories holds up – yet The Conversation

title: Texas hit by deadly floods
description: Flash floods hit central Texas in the USA. Georgie and Phil discuss the story.
story:
Flash floods hit central Texas in the USA on Thursday night and Friday morning. More than 100 people have died in the floods and many are still missing.

The floods caused the Guadalupe river to burst its banks and water levels rose by eight metres in just 45 minutes.

Victims include 27 girls and staff from Camp Mystic a Christian all-girls' summer camp. 

Camp Mystic said in a statement on Monday, "Our hearts are broken alongside our families that are enduring this unimaginable tragedy."
headlines: ‘Unimaginable tragedy’: Texas camp speaks out after 27 campers and counselors die in flooding The Independent Why did deadly Texas floods catch people by surprise? Sky News Trump faces scrutiny over climate funding cuts amid Texas floods Al Jazeera

speak out

  • News of the hospital’s closure caught everyone by surprise. No one knew they were having financial difficulties.
    • face scrutiny experience a close and critical examination

title: Deadly heatwave hits Europe
description: Many European countries are experiencing an extreme heatwave. Beth and Phil discuss.
story:
Many European countries are experiencing an extreme heatwave and are on a red heat alert. This means there is a major risk to life and infrastructure.

Two people in Italy have died because of the heat, while in Turkey, over 50,000 people have been evacuated because of wildfires.

Experts say extreme hot weather, like heatwaves, will happen more often, last for longer and become even more intense as the planet continues to warm.
headlines: European heatwave leaves Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece in sweltering 40C heat Sky News Schools closed and Paris at standstill as France takes brunt of Europe’s heat wave MSN Lethal heat is Europe’s new climate reality Politico

    • new reality a new and different situation to the past

title: Israel-Iran ceasefire
description: A ceasefire is in place after over a week of missile strikes between Israel and Iran.
story:
A ceasefire in the conflict between Israel and Iran is in place.

US President Donald Trump announced the ceasefire after over a week of missile attacks between Israel and Iran. The US also launched air strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities over the weekend.

At first, strikes continued between Israel and Iran after the ceasefire was announced, but now the agreement appears to be holding.

title: Israel-Iran strikes
description: Israel has launched missile strikes on Iran, who have responded with strikes on Israel.
story:
Israel launched an attack on Iran last Friday, targeting nuclear and military facilities.

The strikes killed several senior Iranian military commanders and Iranian nuclear scientists.

Iran retaliated with missile attacks targeting Israel.

Iran's health ministry said at least 224 people have been killed in the Israeli strikes, while Israel says Iranian attacks have killed 24 people.

title: Los Angeles protests: Trump sends Marines
description: Donald Trump sends the Marines to Los Angeles after immigration raids lead to protest
story:
Immigration raids in Los Angeles led to protest, some of which have become violent.

In response, President Trump sent National Guard troops, now supported by US Marines to subdue the protests.

This move was opposed by California state governor, Gavin Newsom as well as the Mayor of Los Angeles, Karen Bass.

Local authorities in California said that the intervention of National Guard troops and Marines could provoke more violence.

title: North Korean secrets revealed by phone
description: A North Korean smartphone has revealed details about how the regime controls its people
story:
The BBC has gained access to a North Korean phone which has been smuggled out of the country.

The phone doesn’t have access to the internet and is designed to make sure its users follow the rules in North Korea, which is closely controlled by its leader Kim Jong-un.

The phone creates a screenshot every five minutes, which is used by the country's authorities to watch the user.

The phone also has an autocorrect function which changes terms used in South Korea to expressions favoued by the North Korean regime.
headlines: Smartphone smuggled out of North Korea shows chilling details implemented by Kim Jong-un's regime LADbible From 'oppa' to comrade: North Korea's phones auto-correct to fit party line India Today This smartphone smuggled out of North Korea is absolutely wild Futurism

  • This TV show is wild. I have no idea what’s going to happen next.

title: Global warming increases risk of cancer in women: Study
description: Global warming increases the risk of cancer in women, a new study has found
story:
Global warming is linked to an increased risk of cancer in women, a recent study has found.

The study included 17 countries in the Middle East and North Africa region – some of the hottest parts of the world.

It found that increased heat is linked to an increase in rates of breast, ovarian, uterine and cervical cancers.

The researchers say countries in this region must take global warming into account in their future cancer control plans.
headlines: Global Warming Could Be Making Cancer In Women More Common And Deadly : Study NDTV Global heating may be fuelling rise in deadly cancers among women The Independent Doctors sound alarm over link between cancer explosion and crisis Trump calls a hoax Daily Mail

title: Human consciousness: Where is it in the brain?
description: Two theories about consciousness have been put to the test by scientists.
story:
Consciousness is everything a person experiences – someone's awareness of their thoughts, feelings, sensations, memories. But where does this happen in the brain?

Scientists haven’t yet agreed on an explanation, but recently, two leading theories were put to the test in a large, research project.

The two theories that were put against each other were very different. For example, for one of them, the front part of the brain is not considered necessary for consciousness. Whereas the other theory argues that consciousness comes from what they call ‘global broadcasting’ across the brain, which does include the front regions.

Both theories made some accurate predictions about what was happening in the brain, but some of the predictions were wrong. “Both theories are incomplete,” said Dr. Ferrante, one of the neuroscientists working on the project.
headlines: Two Theories Face Off to Explain the Origins of Consciousness Scientific American Two Theories of Consciousness Faced Off. The Ref Took a Beating . The New York Times Landmark study puts leading theories of consciousness to the test— neither comes out unscathed University of Birmingham

  • My presentation at work last week went really badly. My confidence really took a beating.

title: Weight loss drugs reduce cancer risk, study finds
description: Weight loss drugs could reduce the risk of cancer by 50%.
story:
Weight-loss drugs like could reduce the risk of getting cancer by half, new research suggests.

Cancer experts are excited by the findings, with one saying that this could be a whole new era of preventative cancer medicine.

Obesity is associated with 13 different cancers. Losing weight reduces the risk, but the researchers have calculated that the weight-loss drugs provide an additional protective effect, beyond just weight loss. 

The authors of the study think this could be because the drugs reduce inflammation in the body.

Weight loss jabs may prevent cancer due to health benefits 'beyond weight loss' Daily Record Weight-loss jabs ‘ halve the risk of cancer’ The Telegraph

title: Octopuses and fish work together
description: Scientists have discovered fish and octopuses that work together to hunt for food.
story:
Scientists have discovered fish and octopuses that work together to hunt for food.

During dives in the red sea, a team of scientists filmed octopuses and fish for 120 hours.

They found that octopuses will sometimes punch fish that aren't working as part of the team.

Experts want to study the underwater behaviour more to find out whether octopuses can remember certain fish who have been bad teammates in the past.

title: Huge power cuts in Spain and Portugal
description: What caused this huge power cut? Learn about this story with Beth and Pippa
story:
Authorities in Spain and Portugal are trying to find out what caused a huge power cut in the countries earlier this week.

The power cut caused chaos across Portugal and Spain and also affected parts of Andorra and France.

Trains didn’t work, businesses had to close and mobile phone networks were also impacted.

Power has now been restored, but the disruption is thought to have cost up to €1.6bn to the Spanish economy.

title: Pope Francis dies
description: What happens after the Pope dies?
story:
Pope Francis died on Monday morning, aged 88, after leading the Roman Catholic Church for more than a decade.

His funeral will take place on Saturday and will be attended by leaders from around the world.

Pope Francis was the first non-European Pope in centuries and the first to come from the Americas.

His death now starts a political process for the Catholic Church to select a new leader. A group of the Catholic Church’s most senior officials – cardinals – will vote for a new Pope in an election known as a conclave.

The Down-to-Earth Pope: Pope Francis Has Died at Eighty-eight New Yorker

title: Sudan war: 'World's worst humanitarian crisis'
description: The war in Sudan is the biggest humanitarian crisis in the world today, say charities
story:
Paramilitaries have declared a rival government in Sudan, two years into a war in the country.

The war has been described by charities and aid agencies as the biggest humanitarian crisis in the world today.

More than 12 million people have been forced to leave their homes because of the war and charities say 30 million people in the country need aid, such as food and medication.

title: World reacts to Trump's tariffs
description: How are Trump's latest tariffs affecting the global economy?
story:
The global economy is in shock after US President Donald Trump introduced a new wave of global tariffs – that’s taxes placed on goods imported into the US from other countries.

The baseline tariff for all countries is 10%, but there are extra tariffs on 60 countries which Trump calls the "worst offenders". Trump has also put 104% tariffs on goods from China, the world's biggest exporter.

It is unclear whether Trump is introducing tariffs to raise revenue and protect American industry, or as a way of getting countries to do what he wants them to do.

title: Myanmar mourns earthquake dead
description: Myanmar has begun five days of national mourning following an earthquake in the country.
story:
Myanmar has begun five days of national mourning, that’s the sadness we feel when someone dies, following an earthquake in the country which has killed more than 2700 people.

The earthquake has caused widespread damage in Myanmar and was also felt in Thailand and parts of China.

Teams are still trying to rescue survivors from collapsed buildings, days after the earthquake hit.

title: Turkey protests after political rival jailed
description: There have been protests in Turkey after the president's main political rival was jailed
story:
Ekrem Imamoglu, mayor of Istanbul, has been jailed on corruption charges.

Since then, there have been days of protests, leading to violent clashes between protestors and the authorities.

Imamoglu is seen as the main political rival to Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who has been either prime minister of president since 2003.

Since being jailed, the main opposition party in the country declared Imamoglu their candidate for the 2028 presidential election.

His university degree had recently been annulled – cancelled – which means he is not allowed to stand for election.

title: Astronauts home after 9 months in space
description: After nine months in space, two Nasa astronauts have finally arrived back on Earth.
story:
After nine months in space, Nasa astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams have finally arrived back on Earth.

Their stay on the International Space Station (ISS) was only supposed to last eight days, but their mission was dramatically extended after the spacecraft that they arrived on, called ‘Starliner’, began to have technical problems.

Starliner was sent back to Earth empty in September 2024, so Butch and Suni needed an alternative spacecraft to take them home. Nine months after they arrived, they’re finally back.

title: Woolly mice: Are woolly mammoths next?
description: Researchers plan to create genetically-altered, mammoth-like elephants in the future.
story:
Scientists have created a genetically modified mouse that's woolly.

The researchers plan to use their woolly mouse to test out other genetic changes before they try to create genetically-altered, mammoth-like elephants in the future.

The company, Colossal Biosciences, hope to use the new mammoths in the fight against global warming.

Critics say the project is unethical and mainly an attempt to gain publicity.

title: 50% adults overweight or obese by 2050: Global study
description: More than half of all adults could be overweight or obese by 2050.
story:
More than half of all adults and a third of children, teenagers and young adults around the world are predicted to be overweight or obese by 2050. The findings come from a new study of global data, covering more than 200 countries, published in The Lancet, a well-known British medical journal.

Researchers warn that if trends continue, global rates of overweight and obese adults would increase significantly, particularly in Asia and Africa, where populations are growing.

Experts say that if governments take urgent action now, there is still time to prevent what they describe as a "profound tragedy".

title: Is vaping as bad as smoking cigarettes?
description: A new UK study has found that vapes are just as bad for health as cigarettes.
story:
53% of current vapers in the UK, that's around 3 million people, used to smoke cigarettes. Many believe that vaping is less harmful than smoking cigarettes. A new study, which will be published soon, questions this.

The study, by Manchester Metropolitan University, has found that e-cigarettes and vapes are just as bad for health as cigarettes.

Researchers gave volunteers fitness tests which measured things like blood flow to their brains.

Results show that long-term users of vapes and e-cigarettes are equally at risk of dementia, heart disease and organ failure as regular cigarette smokers. This is because of damage to artery walls and reduced blood flow.
headlines: Vaping 'more dangerous than smoking', bombshell first-of-its-kind study reveals - it raises risk of THREE deadly diseases Mail Online Deadly side of vaping revealed as bombshell study blows initial theory out the water Daily Star 10-year study to shed light on youth vaping gov.uk

title: Ukraine war: US-Russia peace talks
description: The US and Russia have agreed to start negotiations for ending the war in Ukraine

title: Gaza ceasefire at risk
description: The ceasefire which started in Gaza in January is at risk of collapsing.
story:
There is a ceasefire – that’s a pause in fighting - in Gaza which began on the 19th January.

The terms of the ceasefire deal include the release of hostages taken by Hamas on 7th October 2023, in exchange the release of Palestinian prisoners held in Israel.

The deal also says Israeli forces must leave populated areas, allow displaced Palestinians to return to their homes, and hundreds of aid lorries are to be allowed into Gaza each day. But now, the ceasefire is at risk.

Hamas has announced a delay to the next scheduled release of Israeli hostages, saying Israel has broken the ceasefire agreement. A Hamas spokesperson accused Israel of delaying the return of displaced Palestinians to the north of Gaza, continuing to fire on people and failing to allow in agreed humanitarian aid.

US President Donald Trump has made comments suggesting the US could "take over" and "own" Gaza - a plan which would be considered illegal under international law and has been widely criticised.

Is the ceasefire in Gaza on the verge of breakdown? Middle East Eye
Hamas suspends release of Israeli hostages over ‘violations’ of ceasefire The Guardian

title: Trump's tariffs
description: Why has Trump started imposing tariffs on imports into the USA?  Listen to find out
story:
US President Donald Trump has started imposing tariffs on imports into the USA.

Tariffs make imports more expensive – a cost which is often passed onto consumers who have to pay more for imported products.

Donald Trump has imposed 10% tariffs on all Chinese imports to the US. He had also threatened to impose 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico, but these have been suspended for 30 days.

title: DeepSeek: Chinese AI app shocks tech world
description: Why has this Chinese AI app shocked the tech world? Listen to find out
story:
A Chinese artificial intelligence app called DeepSeek has caught the attention of the global tech industry. It was released on the 20th of January, and has quickly risen to the top of the Apple store’s download charts.

DeepSeek claims the latest model was built using only $5.6 million, whereas ChatGPT’s developer OpenAI spent $5 billion last year alone.

The market value of tech company stocks, like Nvidia, has since fallen dramatically.

title: Trump returns to power
description: Donald Trump has returned to power as US president
story:
President Donald Trump has started his second term as president with lots of executive orders about what he wants to do. Executive orders are written orders which don’t require Congress, that’s the US parliament, to approve them.

Among Trump’s first acts as president are: starting to withdraw from the World Health Organization and the Paris Climate agreement, which is an international agreement to fight Climate change. He also threatened to put tariffs on China, Canada and Mexico and reversed many of his predecessor President Biden’s policies.

title: Kumbh Mela: 400 million to attend world's largest festival
description: A festival so big that it can be seen from space.
story:
The Kumbh Mela festival, the largest religious gathering in the world, has begun in the northern Indian city of Prayagraj. 400 million people are expected to attend throughout the 45-day period, authorities say. The festival can be seen from space.

The Hindu festival is held once every 12 years, but this year it's particularly significant because of a rare alignment between the Sun, the Moon and Jupiter, which happens only once every 144 years.

title: North Korea hypersonic missile claims
description: Has North Korea launched a hypersonic missile?
story:
North Korea has launched a missile which they claim flew at over 12 times the speed of sound and travelled 1500km. The South Korean military says that they believe the claims from North Korea are exaggerated.

Hypersonic missiles, which travel more than 5 times faster than sound and can change direction, are much harder to intercept. Only China, Russia and the US are currently thought to have this technology.

Some people suspect that Russia is helping North Korea to develop advanced missile technology in return for troops to fight in Ukraine.

title: The face of the real Santa Claus
description: Researchers have produced images of the man who Santa Claus is based on.

description: People who have a higher daily step count may have a lower risk of depression.

title: Rebels defeat Assad in Syria
description: Syrian rebels have taken control of the country after defeating Bashar al-Assad's forces

title: South Korea's martial law crisis
description: South Korea's president is facing a political crisis after failing to impose martial law.
story:
South Korea’s president Yoon Suk Yeol declared martial law, asking the armed forces to suspend normal democratic freedoms, for example being able to protest.

Yoon said martial law was needed because of threats from North Korea. But critics say Yoon wanted to use martial law as a response to scandals and problems he faces.

The armed forces were unable to stop National Assembly members voting against this measure.

Facing opposition, president Yoon ended the state of martial law just hours after it had been declared.

President Yoon is now facing calls to resign, and the opposition has launched an attempt to impeach him.

title: Laos: Six dead from possible methanol poisoning
description: Six people have died of suspected methanol poisoning in Laos
story:
Eight hostel staff members have been detained in Laos after six tourists died.

The tourists' deaths were thought to have been caused by drinks that had been contaminated with methanol, a type of alcohol that the human body cannot process.

Vang Vieng is a town popular with backpackers, usually young people who travel on a budget, and has a reputation for cheap alcohol and partying.

According to humanitarian organisation, Medecin Sans Frontieres, Asia has the highest incidence of methanol poisoning, with cases in Indonesia, India, Cambodia, Vietnam and the Philippines.

Methanol is sometimes added to home-made alcohol, but just 30ml can be deadly.
headlines: 6 tourists who died are believed to have drunk tainted alcohol in Laos Business Insider Laos’ methanol poisoning deaths send chill through backpacker paradise Al-Jazeera How an idyllic Laos village turned into a hedonistic party hotspot The Telegraph
keywords:
tainted made dangerous by something harmful
  • The company had to recall the tainted meat.
    • send chill through make worried or afraid
  • Seeing the destruction caused by the earthquake sent a chill through the rescue team.
    • hedonistic related to uncontrolled partying
  • The rock band became known for their hedonistic parties.

title: Ukraine fires US-supplied missiles into Russia
description: President Biden has approved the use of US missiles against targets in Russia
story:
US President Joe Biden has given permission for Ukraine to use landmines supplied by the US in the war with Russia.

It comes after Ukraine was able to use US-supplied long-range missiles to attack inside Russia for the first time.

It is a big change in the war as previously the US had not allowed land mines to be used, or missiles to be fired into Russian territory.

The change comes as the war between Russia and Ukraine hit 1,000 days.
headlines: Where do Russia and Ukraine stand militarily after 1,000 days of conflict? Sky News What will Putin do about Biden’s parting gift to Ukraine? The Spectator Kremlin accuses Biden of ratcheting up nuclear tensions UCA News
keywords:
Where do things stand? What is the situation?

    • parting gift something given to someone who is leaving or by someone who is leaving
  • My professor gave me the parting gift of a recommendation letter for my dream job.
    • ratchet something up increase over time in controlled stages
  • The protest group are ratcheting up their pressure on the government to change the law.

title: Pakistan's worst ever smog
description: The smog in Lahore, Pakistan, is at its worst level ever.
story:
The smog in Lahore, Pakistan, is at its worst level ever, seriously affecting the health of its 13 million residents.

People have been told to stay indoors, schools are closed and vehicles have been banned from the worst affected areas. 

The air quality index in the city has recently reached over 1,000. Anything above 300 is considered dangerous. 

The main cause of this year's smog is a higher number of illegal fires which farmers in Pakistan and neighbouring India use to burn their crops quickly and cheaply.
headlines: Pictures from space show mighty smog choking Lahore BBC News Half of children in Pakistan out of school for second time this year as air pollution hits new highs Save the Children The blurred lines between smog and climate change UCA News

choke stop someone breathing
  • The smoke from the fire was so thick it was choking the crowd.
    • hit new highs higher than ever before
  • She's excited because her company's value has hit new highs.

  • Some say there's a blurred line between love and hate.

title: Donald Trump wins the US Election
description: Donald Trump has won the US presidential election against Democrat Kamala Harris.
story: Donald Trump has won the US presidential election against current Vice-President Kamala Harris. Many experts expected this election to be one of the closest in recent history. Trump has become the first US president in over 130 years to have a gap between his two presidencies. During the campaign, Trump survived two assassination attempts. World leaders have started congratulating Trump on his victory.
headlines: Donald Trump declares 'magnificent victory' in speech to jubilant supporters BBC News Donald Trump closes in on US election victory Politico US votes as polls show Harris and Trump neck and neck Financial Times

jubilant extremely happy because of success

  • Watch as the police close in on the gang members.

  • They’re both so fast. They're neck and neck. Who's going to win?

title: Lost Maya city found in Mexico
description: How has nobody noticed this huge Maya city before?
story: A huge lost city has been found in the jungle in Mexico. The city was built by Maya people hundreds of years ago. Archaeologists believe up to 50,000 people could have lived in the city before Maya civilisations began to collapse in 800AD. The city, named Valeriana by scientists, is only 15km from a main road where Maya people still live today.

    • not even close
     not at all true
  • Will the restaurant be ready to open in time? Not even close. Our chef has quit.

title: India: Bomb threats delay flights
description: Hoax bomb threats have disrupted flights
story:
A large rise in hoax bomb threats has caused chaos around the world with flights having to land in the wrong places or turn around.

A hoax bomb threat is where someone says they have put a bomb somewhere but they’re lying. They can cause lots of problems for airlines and passengers because airlines and authorities have to take the threats seriously in case they’re real.

In the last week, there have been at least 90 fake threats, targeting mostly Indian airlines.

    • mull (something over) think about something carefully
  • I've been mulling over whether to move house for a while now and I think I've finally made a decision.

title: Earth's climate defences failing
description: Scientists have found problems with the Earth's natural defences against climate change.
story:
Scientists have found that the Earth's natural defences against climate change didn't work properly in 2023.

The Earth's oceans and land usually take in about half of all human carbon emissions.

But a study found that last year, the hottest on record, forests, plants and soil took in almost no carbon from the atmosphere.

Scientists are concerned that wildfires and droughts are impacting these natural processes, which are essential for fighting climate change, from working properly.
headlines: Trees and land absorbed almost no CO2 last year. Is nature’s carbon sink failing? The Guardian Carbon sink broken? Last year, trees and land barely absorbed any CO2 Down to Earth Wildfires weaken global carbon sink, putting climate targets at risk Meteored

    • carbon sink something that absorbs carbon from the atmosphere and stores it
  • Not many people know that oceans are great carbon sinks.

title: AI critic wins Nobel Prize... for AI
description: A man has won a Nobel Prize for his work on AI, though he now warns of its dangers.
story:
The Nobel Prize in Physics has been given to two scientists, Geoffrey Hinton and John Hopfield, for their work on machine learning, a kind of technology used by Artificial intelligence software.

But one of the winners of the award, Geoffrey Hinton, now believes that AI technology could be dangerous in the future.

Professor Hinton resigned from his job at Google in 2023, and has warned that machines that could eventually become smarter than humans.
headlines: ‘ Godfather of AI’ who warned technology could end humanity wins Nobel Prize Evening Standard Brit scientist Geoffrey Hinton dubbed 'the Godfather of AI' wins Nobel Prize for physics Mirror AI doomsayer wins Nobel Prize for key research Politico

title: Iran attacks Israel after invasion of Lebanon
description: Israel invades Lebanon. Iran fights back.
story:
The Israeli prime minister has said that his country will respond to Iran’s missile attack on Israel on Tuesday night.

Iran fired about 180 missiles at Israel. Most were intercepted, which means stopped.

Iran’s attack followed Israel’s invasion of Lebanon, which resulted in the killing of the Hezbollah leader.

Lebanese authorities say that over 1,000 people have been killed in the last two weeks and that over a million people have had to leave their homes.

  • The latest offensive left few survivors.

title: MrBeast named in lawsuit
description: YouTuber MrBeast has been named in court documents about the treatment of TV contestants.
story:
MrBeast, real name Jimmy Donaldson, runs the largest YouTube channel in the world.

He is producing a reality show, Beast Games, with a $5m prize together with Amazon.

Serious allegations have emerged around the conditions for contestants and his company has been served with a lawsuit.

Allegations include exposing people to sexual harrassment, being misleading about the chances of winning, and restricting access to food and medication.

Our colleagues at BBC News asked MrBeast for comment, but at the time this programme was published, he hadn't responded.
headlines: MrBeast faces legal challenge: Lawsuit alleges toxic environment on set The Indian Express On the cusp of mainstream stardom, MrBeast is being sued Stuff Shocker : Turns Out MrBeast Is the Worst Jezebel

title: Shanghai: Worst typhoon in 75 years
description: The worst typhoon since 1949 has hit Shanghai. Beth and Phil walk you through this story
story:
On Monday, Shanghai was hit by Typhoon Bebinca, the strongest since 1949, with wind speeds of over 150km reported.

25 million people were advised to stay at home and 400,000 people were evacuated by Chinese authorities.

Shanghai is now fixing the damage – over 1,800 trees have blown down and 30,000 homes have lost power.

title: Australia plans kids' social media ban
description: Australian Prime Minister announces plans to ban children from social media sites
story:
Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced plans to ban young people from social media sites. The ban is likely to apply to children under 14.

Critics have questioned whether it can be actually enforced.

Some people are worried that this approach may block young people from information about important issues.

title: German far right wins state election
description: The far-right party AfD has won a state election in Thuringia, Germany.
story:
The far-right party AfD (Alternative fur Deutschland) has won a state election in Thuringia, Germany.

The AfD won the highest number of seats in the election but could struggle to form a state government as other parties are refusing to work with them.

AfD voters have raised concerns about asylum and immigration, and green policies. They also want to stop German military aid to Ukraine.

title: UN: Rising sea levels disaster for all
description: The UN Secretary-General has warned that rising sea levels are going to be disastrous.
story:
The United Nations Secretary-General, António Guterres, has warned that rising sea levels are going to be disastrous not just the Pacific Islands, but for everyone across the globe.

His comments come after two UN reports on the state of the climate.

The UN have said there is an obligation on the G20 to help because those countries cause 80% of emissions.

title: Chimps chat like we do
description: Study reveals that chimps take turns in conversation, just like us!
story:
A study has shown that chimpanzees take turns in conversations in a similar way to humans.

Chimps use gestures to communicate. Reseachers observed that chimps allow others to make their point, before quickly stepping in with a response. Chimpanzees also interrupt each other, just as humans do.

This communciation allows the animals to share food and organise their activities.

Chimps share humans' ' snappy ' conversational style BBC News Chimpanzees communicate in similar quick-fire fashion to humans, study shows The Guardian

title: Ukraine fights back inside Russia
description: Ukrainian soldiers hold towns in Russia in military operation
story:
The Ukrainian military says its troops now hold 74 towns and villages in Russia after a military operation.

It’s a big moment in the war as it’s the first time Ukraine have completed a significant attack across the Russian border.

Thousands of people have been asked to evacuate Kursk – a region of Western Russia where the fighting is happening.

Russia’s president Vladimir Putin has said Russia will retaliate.

title: Bangladesh protests: PM quits
description: Bangladesh's Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has quit and escaped the country.
story:
Bangladesh's Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has quit and escaped the country.

Around 300 people have died in violence between protestors, opponents and security forces in recent weeks.

After a large protest in the capital Dhaka calling for the Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's resignation, she stepped down and escaped the country.

title: Venezuela election chaos
description: President Maduro has claimed victory in the Venezuelan elections, but is the result fair?
story:
President Nicolas Maduro has claimed victory in the Venezuelan elections, but opposition politicians say their candidate Edmundo Gonzalez won 73% of the vote, which is what was predicted in opinion polls.

The disagreement has lead to protests across Venezuela, and many countries in the region have expressed doubts at how accurate the election results are.

The United Nations have said Venezuelan authorities should release more data from the elections.

title: Biden out, Harris in
description: The 2024 US presidential race - learn the latest
story:
US President Joe Biden has ended his campaign to become president again, saying "it is in the best interest of my party and the country".

Biden was under intense pressure from fellow Democrats to quit after poor performances at recent events such as a debate against Donald Trump in June.

Biden’s Vice-President Kamala Harris now has support from senior politicians to become the Democrat Party's official candidate for president.

She would then face Republican nominee Donald Trump in November's presidential election.

title: Trump assassination attempt
description: The US reacts to an assassination attempt on Donald Trump
story:
People in the US have been reacting after an assassination attempt on Donald Trump.

Thomas Matthew Crooks shot at Trump as he spoke at an event in Pennsylvania, injuring the former president’s ear.

One man in the audience was killed in the attack and two others were seriously injured.

Security officers then shot the gunman dead. The exact reason for his attack is unclear.

title: Third of adults inactive
description: Around 1.8 billion people in the world are physically inactive, according to WHO study
story:
A World Health Organisation (WHO) study has found that around 1.8 billion people in the world are inactive.

The results are part of a worldwide study and show that more people are inactive globally than the last study in 2010.

Scientists have linked a lack of physical activity to lots of serious health problems, including an increase in the risk of stokes, heart attacks, diabetes and some cancers.

Neil and Georgie explain this news story and teach you some useful vocabulary.

title: Trump legal ruling
description: New ruling means Trump cannot be punished for official actions committed as president
story:
The US Supreme Court has said Donald Trump cannot be punished for official actions he committed as president.

The ruling means that any US president, including ex-president Trump, can't be criminally prosecuted for work they do as part of their job as president, even if it's something considered illegal for everyone else. 

Some people are worried about this, while others think it is necessary to stop criminal prosecution influencing presidential decision-making.

Neil and Beth explain this news story and teach you some useful vocabulary.

title: Julian Assange walks free
description: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange walks free from US court
story:
WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has walked free from a US court after pleading guilty in a deal to end a legal battle that has lasted years.

His organisation, WikiLeaks, published secret US military records in 2010. Assange has now pleaded guilty to one charge connected to espionage.

He’s now back in his home country, Australia, and will not have to go to US prison. 

Neil and Beth explain this news story and teach you some useful vocabulary.

title: Putin in North Korea
description: Vladimir Putin has met Kim Jong Un in North Korea.
story:
Russian president Vladimir Putin has met North Korean leader Kim Jong Un.

During the visit, Kim Jong Un said he fully supports Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

The leaders have signed a deal to help each other in case of aggression against either country.

title: Far right performs well in EU election
description: The far right has performed well in the latest European Union elections.
story:
The far right has performed well in the latest European Union elections, but overall the centre-right remains strongest. 

The French president Emmanuel Macron called a surprise national election after his centrist party performed badly.

In other parts of the EU, left-wing and green parties increased their votes.

title: Brazil floods
description: Southern Brazil has been hit by the worst flooding in 80 years.
story:
Heavy rains in the southern Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul have left hundreds of towns under water.

At least 85 people have died in the floods and about 150,000 have had to leave their homes. More than 130 people are still missing.

More heavy rain is expected in the region this week.
